title-group.article-title: A posteriori error estimates for the Johnson–Nédélec FEM–BEM coupling

article-meta.aff: Institute for Analysis and Scientific Computing, Vienna University of Technology, Wiedner Hauptstraße 8-10, A-1040 Wien, Austria

license.license-p: This document may be redistributed and reused, subject to certain conditions.

abstract.p: Only very recently, Sayas [The validity of Johnson–Nédélec's BEM-FEM coupling on polygonal interfaces. SIAM J Numer Anal 2009;47:3451–63] proved that the Johnson–Nédélec one-equation approach from [On the coupling of boundary integral and finite element methods. Math Comput 1980;35:1063–79] provides a stable coupling of finite element method (FEM) and boundary element method (BEM). In our work, we now adapt the analytical results for different a posteriori error estimates developed for the symmetric FEM–BEM coupling to the Johnson–Nédélec coupling. More precisely, we analyze the weighted-residual error estimator, the two-level error estimator, and different versions of (h−h/2)-based error estimators. In numerical experiments, we use these estimators to steer h-adaptive algorithms, and compare the effectivity of the different approaches.

abstract.title: Highlights
abstract.p: ► A posteriori error estimators for Johnson-Nedéléc one-equation coupling of FEM and BEM. ► Weighted-residual estimator. ► Two-level hierarchical estimator. ► (h-h/2)-based estimator. ► Numerical comparison of related h-adaptive algorithms.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The FEM–BEM coupling is often used for interface problems in unbounded domains, where, e.g. non-linearities are present in a bounded domain and the material is isotropic in the exterior, cf. [22,24,36,34]. The symmetric FEM–BEM coupling was proposed and analyzed by Costabel [22] and attracted most attention in the mathematical literature. In engineering, however, more often the coupling procedure proposed by Johnson and Nédélec [37] is used since it only involves two integral operators instead of four. Only very recently, Sayas [46] proved that the Johnson–Nédélec coupling is well-posed even on polygonal domains, whereas numerical evidence of this was already known for many years, cf. e.g. [23].

To the best of our knowledge, the numerical analysis of a posteriori FEM–BEM error estimators has only been derived for the symmetric coupling. Most of the results follow the concept of two-level error estimation introduced in [42], see also the recent work [39] and the references therein. Other approaches include residual-based error estimators which have first been studied in [20], and recently also (h−h/2)-based error estimators [5].

In this work, we transfer these three classes of a posteriori error estimators from the symmetric coupling to the Johnson–Nédélec coupling. As model problem serves, for the ease of presentation, the interface problem for the Laplacian in two dimensions with an inhomogeneous volume force in the interior. We then formulate adaptive mesh-refining algorithms for each of these three approaches. In numerical experiments, we finally compare the effectiveness.

The detailed outline of this work reads as follows: In Section 2.1, we state our model problem and fix the notation of the integral operators involved. Section 2.2 introduces the Galerkin discretization and sketches the result of Sayas [46]. For some implementational reasons, we also discretize the given boundary data to which integral operators are applied. This allows to work with discrete integral operators, i.e. matrices, in the implementation and leads to some perturbed Galerkin formulation given in Section 2.3.

Section 3 is the heart of this work and contains the a posteriori error analysis. First, we collect the necessary notation in Sections 3.1 and 3.2. The a posteriori error control of the approximation error for the boundary data is discussed in Section 3.3. In Section 3.4, we study the residual error estimator ϱℓϱℓ from [20]. In Section 3.5, we recall the (h−h/2)-error estimator μℓμℓ from [5] and discuss the so-called saturation assumption, whereas Section 3.6 is concerned with the two-level error estimator τℓτℓ from [42]. With certain modifications of the analysis from [5,20,42], we transfer these error estimators from the symmetric coupling to the Johnson–Nédélec coupling and can formulate and prove the according results. However, we stress that, first, our version of ϱℓϱℓ is improved in the sense that it involves volume oscillations instead of the volume residual terms and, second, we also prove global equivalence μℓ ≃ τℓμℓ≃τℓ of (h−h/2)- and two-level error estimator. Finally, a short Section 3.7 provides local relations of τℓτℓ and ϱℓϱℓ.

Section 4 considers an experiment from the literature for which uniform and adaptive mesh-refinement are compared with respect to empirical convergence rate and computational time. Finally, we conclude our work in Section 5 with an overview on the analytical and numerical results of this paper. Moreover, we state possible generalizations of our results for 3D problems and pose some questions for further research.

sec.title: Model problem
sec.p: We consider the linear interface problem(1)−Δuint=finΩint≔Ω,−Δuext=0inΩext≔R2⧹Ω¯,uint−uext=u0onΓ,∂nuint−∂nuext=ϕ0onΓ,uext(x)=O(|x|−1)as|x|→∞.Here, Ω is a bounded Lipschitz domain in ℝ2R2 with boundary Γ ≔ ∂ ΩΓ≔∂Ω and exterior unit normal vector n. The given data satisfy f ∈ L2(Ω)f∈L2(Ω), u0 ∈ H1 / 2(Γ)u0∈H1/2(Γ), and ϕ0 ∈ H − 1 / 2(Γ)ϕ0∈H−1/2(Γ). The space H1 / 2(Γ)H1/2(Γ) is precisely the space of all traces of functions from H1(Ω)H1(Ω), and H − 1 / 2(Γ)H−1/2(Γ) is the dual of H1 / 2(Γ)H1/2(Γ) with respect to the extended L2(Γ)-scalarL2(Γ)-scalar product. To guarantee the solvability of (1), we need the data to satisfy 〈ϕ0, 1〉Γ + 〈f, 1〉Ω = 0〈ϕ0,1〉Γ+〈f,1〉Ω=0. As usual, (1) is understood in the weak sense, and the sought solutions satisfy uint ∈ H1(Ω)uint∈H1(Ω) and uext∈Hℓoc1(Ωext)={v:Ωext→R:∀K⊂Ωextcompactv∈H1(K)} with ∇uext ∈ L2(Ωext)∇uext∈L2(Ωext).

Problem (1) is equivalently stated via the Johnson–Nédélec FEM–BEM coupling proposed in [37]: Find u ≔ (u, ϕ) ∈ ℋ ≔ H1(Ωint)×H − 1 / 2(Γ)u≔(u,ϕ)∈H≔H1(Ωint)×H−1/2(Γ) such that 〈∇u, ∇v〉Ω − 〈ϕ, v〉Γ = 〈f, v〉Ω + 〈ϕ0, v〉Γ for all v ∈ H1(Ωint), 〈∇u,∇v〉Ω−〈ϕ,v〉Γ=〈f,v〉Ω+〈ϕ0,v〉Γforallv∈H1(Ωint),(2)〈ψ, (½ − 𝔎)u + 𝔙ϕ〉Γ = 〈ψ, (½ − 𝔎)u0〉Γ for all ψ ∈ H − 1 / 2(Γ).〈ψ,12−Ku+Vϕ〉Γ=〈ψ,(12−K)u0〉Γforallψ∈H−1/2(Γ).Here, 𝔙 denotes the simple-layer potential and 𝔎 denotes the double-layer potential. With(3)G(z) ≔ − ½log|z| for z ∈ ℝ2 ⧹ {0}G(z)≔−12πlog|z|forz∈R2⧹{0}the fundamental solution of the 2D Laplacian, these integral operators formally read for x ∈ Γx∈Γ as follows:(4)(𝔙ψ)(x) = ∫ΓG(x − y)ψ(y) dΓ(y), (Vψ)(x)=∫ΓG(x−y)ψ(y)dΓ(y),(5)(𝔎v)(x) = ∫Γ∂ n(y)G(x − y)v(y) dΓ(y).(Kv)(x)=∫Γ∂n(y)G(x−y)v(y)dΓ(y).By continuous extension, these definitions provide linear boundary integral operators 𝔙 ∈ L(H − 1 / 2(Γ); H1 / 2(Γ))V∈L(H−1/2(Γ);H1/2(Γ)) and 𝔎 ∈ L(H1 / 2(Γ); H1 / 2(Γ))K∈L(H1/2(Γ);H1/2(Γ)). By scaling of Ω, we may assume that diam(Ω) < 1diam(Ω)<1 to ensure the uniform ellipticity of 𝔙, i.e. ∥ψ∥H−1/2(Γ)2≲〈ψ,Vψ〉Γforallψ∈H−1/2(Γ).In particular, 〈ϕ, ψ〉𝔙 ≔ 〈ϕ, 𝔙ψ〉Γ〈ϕ,ψ〉V≔〈ϕ,Vψ〉Γ is a scalar product, and ∥ψ∥V2≔〈ψ,Vψ〉Γforψ∈H−1/2(Γ)defines an equivalent norm on H − 1 / 2(Γ)H−1/2(Γ). The reader is referred to e.g. [41] for proofs and further details on these integral operators. The link between (1) and (2) is provided by u = uintu=uint and ϕ = ∂ nuextϕ=∂nuext, and uextuext is then given by the third Green's formula(6)uext(x)=K˜(u−u0)(x)−V˜ϕ(x)forx∈Ωext,where the potentials V˜ and K˜ formally denote the operators 𝔙 and 𝔎, but are now evaluated in ΩextΩext instead of Γ. Note carefully that we do not use a notational difference for the function u ∈ H1(Ω)u∈H1(Ω) and its trace u ∈ H1 / 2(Γ)u∈H1/2(Γ), for which we compute the boundary integral (½ − 𝔎)u(12−K)u in (2).

We stress that the second equation of the Johnson–Nédélec FEM–BEM coupling (2) is the same as for the mathematically well-studied symmetric coupling. It has already been proved in [37] that problem (2) is well-posed on the continuous level, i.e. it admits a unique solution u = (u, ϕ) ∈ ℋu=(u,ϕ)∈H.

sec.title: Galerkin discretization
sec.p: Let 𝒯ℓTℓ be a regular triangulation of Ω into triangles Tj ∈ 𝒯ℓTj∈Tℓ and EℓΓ a partition of the coupling boundary Γ into piecewise affine line segments Ej∈EℓΓ. Throughout, the index ℓ ∈ ℕ0ℓ∈N0 indicates the current step of the adaptive loop considered below. We use a conforming discretization with continuous and 𝒯ℓ-piecewiseTℓ-piecewise affine finite elements in Ω and EℓΓ-piecewise constants on Γ, i.e. the discrete spaces read(7)Xℓ≔S1(Tℓ)×P0(EℓΓ)⊂H1(Ω)×H−1/2(Γ)=H.We stress that our analysis does not enforce any coupling of EℓΓ and 𝒯ℓTℓ. However, for the ease of presentation and implementation, we will assume throughout that the boundary mesh EℓΓ=Tℓ|Γ is obtained by restriction of the triangulation 𝒯ℓTℓ to the boundary Γ.

The Galerkin formulation of (2) then reads as follows: Find Uℓ⋆≔(Uℓ⋆,Φℓ⋆)∈Xℓ such that 〈∇Uℓ⋆,∇Vℓ〉Ω−〈Φℓ⋆,Vℓ〉Γ=〈f,Vℓ〉Ω+〈ϕ0,Vℓ〉Γ,(8)〈Ψℓ,(12−K)Uℓ⋆+VΦℓ⋆〉Γ=〈Ψℓ,(12−K)u0〉Γfor all Vℓ ≔ (Vℓ, Ψℓ) ∈ 𝒳ℓVℓ≔(Vℓ,Ψℓ)∈Xℓ. Only very recently [46, Theorem 2], it has been proven that the discrete formulation (8) is well-posed and admits a unique Galerkin solution Uℓ⋆∈Xℓ. We stress that the following result applies, in particular, also to the continuous formulation (2) and provides an alternate proof for the existence and uniqueness of a solution of the Johnson–Nédélec FEM–BEM coupling. Proposition 1Sayas [46]
Suppose thatXℓXℓis a closed subspace ofH1(Ω)H1(Ω)andYℓYℓis a closed subspace ofH − 1 / 2(Γ)H−1/2(Γ)which satisfy(9)1 ∈ Xℓ as well as 1 ∈ Yℓ, 1∈Xℓaswellas1∈Yℓ,i.e. the discrete spaces contain the constant functions. With𝒳ℓ ≔ Xℓ×YℓXℓ≔Xℓ×Yℓ, the linear operatorH:Xℓ→Xℓ⁎(10)(ℍUℓ)(Vℓ) ≔ 〈∇Uℓ, ∇Vℓ〉Ω − 〈Φℓ, Vℓ〉Γ + 〈Ψℓ, (½ − 𝔎)Uℓ + 𝔙Φℓ〉Γ(HUℓ)(Vℓ)≔〈∇Uℓ,∇Vℓ〉Ω−〈Φℓ,Vℓ〉Γ+〈Ψℓ,(12−K)Uℓ+VΦℓ〉ΓforUℓ = (Uℓ, Φℓ)Uℓ=(Uℓ,Φℓ), Vℓ = (Vℓ, Ψℓ) ∈ 𝒳ℓVℓ=(Vℓ,Ψℓ)∈Xℓdefines an isomorphism, where the bounds of the operator norms ∥ ℍ ∥ ∥H∥and ∥ ℍ − 1 ∥ ∥H−1∥depend only onΩ, but not on the chosen spacesXℓXℓandYℓYℓ. In particular, the variational form(8)admits a unique solutionUℓ⋆∈Xℓ. Moreover, there holds the Céa-type quasi-optimality(11)‖|u−Uℓ⋆‖|≤CoptminVℓ∈Xℓ‖|u−Vℓ‖|with‖|v‖|2≔∥v∥H1(Ω)2+∥ψ∥V2 for v = (v, ψ) ∈ ℋv=(v,ψ)∈H, and the constant Copt > 0Copt>0 depends only on Ω, but not on 𝒳ℓXℓ or the given data f, ϕ0ϕ0, and u0.

sec.title: Perturbed Galerkin discretization
sec.p: The right-hand side of (8) involves the evaluation of 𝔎u0Ku0, which can be computed by methods proposed in [19,44,45]. In this work, we will follow another approach. We propose to approximate at least the given trace data u0 ∈ H1 / 2(Γ)u0∈H1/2(Γ) by appropriate discrete functions. One reason for this is that so-called fast methods for boundary integral operators usually deal with discrete functions, cf. [43]. Another reason for this, which is related with the question of convergence of adaptive methods, is discussed at the end of Section 5.4. Following [5,6], we assume additional regularity u0 ∈ H1(Γ)u0∈H1(Γ), and consider the nodal interpolant(12)U0,ℓ≔Iℓu0=∑j=1nu0(zj)ζj∈S1(EℓΓ),where zj ∈ Γzj∈Γ denotes a node of EℓΓ and where ζjζj is the associated EℓΓ-piecewise linear and continuous hat function, i.e. ζj(zk) = δjkζj(zk)=δjk. Now, the perturbed Galerkin formulation reads as follows: Find Uℓ ≔ (Uℓ, Φℓ) ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ≔(Uℓ,Φℓ)∈Xℓ such that 〈∇Uℓ, ∇Vℓ〉Ω − 〈Φℓ, Vℓ〉Γ = 〈f, Vℓ〉Ω + 〈ϕ0, Vℓ〉Γ, 〈∇Uℓ,∇Vℓ〉Ω−〈Φℓ,Vℓ〉Γ=〈f,Vℓ〉Ω+〈ϕ0,Vℓ〉Γ,(13)〈Ψℓ, (½ − 𝔎)Uℓ + 𝔙Φℓ〉Γ = 〈Ψℓ, (½ − 𝔎)U0, ℓ〉Γ, 〈Ψℓ,(12−K)Uℓ+VΦℓ〉Γ=〈Ψℓ,(12−K)U0,ℓ〉Γ,for all (Vℓ, Ψℓ) ∈ 𝒳ℓ(Vℓ,Ψℓ)∈Xℓ. Compared to (8), the only difference is that (13) involves the approximate data U0, ℓU0,ℓ instead of u0 on the right-hand side. Consequently, Proposition 1 applies and proves that (13) has a unique solution Uℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓ.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: Let 𝒯ℓTℓ be a regular triangulation of Ω into triangles which is obtained by adaptive local refinement of an initial triangulation 𝒯0T0. Then, EℓΓ=Tℓ|Γ denotes the induced partition of Γ, i.e. the set of all boundary edges. Let EℓΩ denote the set of all edges of the volume triangulation 𝒯ℓTℓ which lie inside Ω, i.e. for E∈EℓΩ exist unique elements T + , T − ∈ 𝒯ℓT+,T−∈Tℓ with E = T + ∩ T − E=T+∩T−. We then denote the corresponding edge patch by ωℓ, E ≔ T + ∪ T − ωℓ,E≔T+∪T−. Furthermore, we denote by 𝒦ℓKℓ the set of nodes of 𝒯ℓTℓ. For z ∈ 𝒦ℓz∈Kℓ, denote by ℰℓ, zEℓ,z the set of all edges E′∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ which have z as a node.

To exclude some pathological cases, we restrict ourselves to meshes 𝒯ℓTℓ which meet the following conditions:•
each element T ∈ 𝒯ℓT∈Tℓ has at most one edge on the boundary Γ,•
each interior edge E∈EℓΩ has at most one node on the boundary Γ.We stress that these assumptions are essentially conditions on the initial triangulation 𝒯0T0.

Let diam(ω)diam(ω) denote the Euclidean diameter of a set ω ⊂ ℝ2ω⊂R2. For x∈τ∈Tℓ∪EℓΓ, we define the local mesh-width function by hℓ(x) ≔ diam(τ)hℓ(x)≔diam(τ). This definition provides functions hℓ ∈ L ∞ (Ω)hℓ∈L∞(Ω) as well as hℓ ∈ L ∞ (Γ)hℓ∈L∞(Γ) and hℓ∈L∞(⋃EℓΩ), where ⋃EℓΩ denotes the interior skeleton of 𝒯ℓTℓ.

sec.title: Local mesh-refinement
sec.p: For the local refinement of the volume mesh 𝒯ℓTℓ, we use newest vertex bisection with the following conventions, cf. Fig. 1: for marked triangles, we mark all three edges, and all marked edges are bisected. We refer to [49, Chapter 5] for details on newest vertex bisection. By others, this mesh-refinement ensures uniform shape regularity of 𝒯ℓTℓ. More precisely, the shape regularity constant(14)σ(𝒯ℓ) ≔ max {diam(T)2 / |T|:T ∈ 𝒯ℓ}σ(Tℓ)≔max{diam(T)2/|T|:T∈Tℓ}depends only on the initial mesh 𝒯0T0, i.e.(15)supℓ∈Nσ(Tℓ)≤Cσ(T0),where C > 0C>0 depends only on the labeling of the reference edges in 𝒯0T0. Marking of an element E∈EℓΓ=Tℓ|Γ means marking of certain edges of some triangles T ∈ 𝒯ℓT∈Tℓ for newest vertex bisection. We stress that this guarantees that marked edges E are split into two sons of half length. Moreover, due to uniform shape regularity (15) of 𝒯ℓTℓ, there automatically holds(16)supℓ∈Nκ(EℓΓ)≤Cκ(E0Γ)for the K-mesh constant (or: local mesh-ratio)(17)κ(EℓΓ)≔max{diam(E)/diam(E′):E,E′∈EℓΓwithE∩E′≠∅},and the constant C > 0C>0 depends only on 𝒯0T0. Finally, there holds nestedness S1(Tℓ)⊆S1(Tℓ+1),P0(EℓΓ)⊆P0(Eℓ+1Γ)whenceconsequentlyXℓ⊆Xℓ+1.

sec.title: Error control of data approximation
sec.p: In the following, we consider a continuous auxiliary problem, where the right-hand side is given as in (13): Find uℓ ≔ (uℓ, ϕℓ) ∈ ℋuℓ≔(uℓ,ϕℓ)∈H such that 〈∇uℓ, ∇v〉Ω − 〈ϕℓ, v〉Γ = 〈f, v〉Ω + 〈ϕ0, v〉Γ, 〈∇uℓ,∇v〉Ω−〈ϕℓ,v〉Γ=〈f,v〉Ω+〈ϕ0,v〉Γ,(18)〈ψ, (½ − 𝔎)uℓ + 𝔙ϕℓ〉Γ = 〈ψ, (½ − 𝔎)U0, ℓ〉Γ〈ψ,(12−K)uℓ+Vϕℓ〉Γ=〈ψ,(12−K)U0,ℓ〉Γfor all v = (v, ψ) ∈ ℋv=(v,ψ)∈H. By definition, Uℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓ then is a Galerkin approximation of uℓ ∈ ℋuℓ∈H so that the quasi-optimality (11) holds with u and Uℓ⋆ replaced by uℓuℓ and UℓUℓ, respectively.

For the symmetric FEM–BEM coupling for some non-linear interface problem, the following result is already stated in [5, Proposition 1]: Proposition 2
Withu, uℓ ∈ ℋu,uℓ∈Hthe continuous solutions of(2) and (18)andUℓ⋆,Uℓ∈Xℓthe corresponding Galerkin solutions of(8) and (13), it holds(19)C1−1‖|Uℓ⋆−Uℓ‖|≤‖|u−uℓ‖|≤C2oscΓ,ℓwithoscΓ,ℓ≔∥hℓ1/2(u0−U0,ℓ)′∥L2(Γ),where(·)′(·)′denotes the arclength derivative alongΓ. WhileC1 > 0C1>0depends only onΩ, the constantC2 > 0C2>0depends additionally onσ(𝒯0)σ(T0).Proof
According to linearity, Uℓ⋆−Uℓ∈Xℓ is the Galerkin approximation of u − uℓ ∈ ℋu−uℓ∈H. Therefore, the quasi-optimality (11) proves ‖|Uℓ⋆−Uℓ‖|≤‖|(u−uℓ)−(Uℓ⋆−Uℓ)‖|+‖|u−uℓ‖|≲‖|u−uℓ‖|.Recall that the linear mapping ℍ:ℋ → ℋ⁎H:H→H⁎ from (10) is an isomorphism. Therefore, there holds ‖|u − uℓ‖| ≃ ∥ ℍu − ℍuℓ ∥ ℋ⁎ ≃ ∥ u0 − U0, ℓ ∥ H1 / 2(Γ)‖|u−uℓ‖|≃∥Hu−Huℓ∥H⁎≃∥u0−U0,ℓ∥H1/2(Γ)since only the trace data differ. By definition, there holds u0 − U0, ℓ = (1 − Iℓ)u0u0−U0,ℓ=(1−Iℓ)u0. Nodal interpolation on the one-dimensional manifold Γ satisfies(20)C3−1∥v−Iℓv∥H1/2(Γ)≤∥hℓ1/2(v−Iℓv)′∥L2(Γ)≤∥hℓ1/2v′∥L2(Γ)forallv∈H1(Γ),see [12, Theorem 1; 16, Corollary 3.4; 28, Lemma 2.2], where the constant C3 > 0C3>0 depends only on Γ and an upper bound of the local mesh-ratio κ(EℓΓ). □□

sec.title: Residual-based error estimator
sec.p:
Let [∂ nUℓ]|E[∂nUℓ]|E denote the jump of ∂ nUℓ∂nUℓ over the edge E∈EℓΩ. We assume additional regularity ϕ0 ∈ L2(Γ)ϕ0∈L2(Γ) for the given data and define the edge jump contributions by γℓ2≔∑E∈EℓΩγℓ(E)2withγℓ(E)≔∥hℓ1/2[∂nUℓ]∥L2(E)as well as the edge oscillations by oscΩ,ℓ2≔∑E∈EℓΩoscΩ,ℓ(E)2withoscΩ,ℓ(E)≔∥hℓ(f−fE)∥L2(ωℓ,E),where fE = |ωℓ, E| − 1∫ωℓ, Ef dxfE=|ωℓ,E|−1∫ωℓ,Efdx denotes the integral mean of f over ωℓ, Eωℓ,E. Lemma 3
The following local estimates hold:(i)
oscΩ, ℓ(E) ≤ C4 ∥ hℓf ∥ L2(ωℓ, E)oscΩ,ℓ(E)≤C4∥hℓf∥L2(ωℓ,E)for allE∈EℓΩ,(ii)
∥ hℓf ∥ L2(T) ≤ C5(γℓ(ℰℓ, z) + oscΩ, ℓ(ℰℓ, z)) for all z ∈ (𝒦ℓ ∩ T) ⧹ Γ∥hℓf∥L2(T)≤C5(γℓ(Eℓ,z)+oscΩ,ℓ(Eℓ,z))forallz∈(Kℓ∩T)⧹Γ,where we abbreviate e.g. γℓ(ℰℓ, z)2 = ∑ E ∈ ℰℓ, zγℓ(E)2γℓ(Eℓ,z)2=∑E∈Eℓ,zγℓ(E)2. The constantsC4, C5 > 0C4,C5>0depend only on the shape regularityσ(𝒯0)σ(T0)of the initial mesh.Proof
The first estimate follows by the best approximation property of fE. The proof of the second estimate is found e.g. in [33, Lemma 4] and relies on certain inverse-type estimates as well as on the fact that newest vertex bisection only leads to finitely many shapes of triangles. □□

We now have the following reliability result for a residual-based a posteriori error estimate. Theorem 4
Suppose thatuℓ ∈ ℋuℓ∈His the unique solution of(18)andUℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓis its Galerkin approximation(13). Assume additional regularityϕ0 ∈ L2(Γ)ϕ0∈L2(Γ). Then, there holds(21)C6−1‖|uℓ−Uℓ‖|≤ϱℓ≔(oscΩ,ℓ2+γℓ2+∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ)∥L2(Γ)2+∥hℓ1/2((12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ)′∥L2(Γ)2)1/2,where the constantC6 > 0C6>0depends only onΩandσ(𝒯0)σ(T0).Proof
We consider the isomorphism ℍ:ℋ → ℋ⁎H:H→H⁎ from (10) and the functional Fℓ ∈ ℋ⁎Fℓ∈H⁎ defined by(22)Fℓ(v) ≔ 〈f, v〉Ω + 〈ϕ0, v〉Γ + 〈ψ, (½ − 𝔎)U0, ℓ〉Γ for v = (v, ψ) ∈ ℋ.Fℓ(v)≔〈f,v〉Ω+〈ϕ0,v〉Γ+〈ψ,(12−K)U0,ℓ〉Γforv=(v,ψ)∈H.Note that (18) is equivalently stated by (ℍuℓ)(v) = Fℓ(v) for all v ∈ ℋ, (Huℓ)(v)=Fℓ(v)forallv∈H,whereas the Galerkin (13) reads (ℍUℓ)(Vℓ) = Fℓ(Vℓ) for all Vℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓ.(HUℓ)(Vℓ)=Fℓ(Vℓ)forallVℓ∈Xℓ.This and the fact that ℍ is an isomorphism yields(23)‖|uℓ−Uℓ‖|≃supv∈H⧹{0}|Fℓ(v)−HUℓ(v)|‖|v‖|=supv∈H⧹{0}|Fℓ(v−Vℓ)−HUℓ(v−Vℓ)|‖|v‖|for all Vℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓVℓ∈Xℓ. To estimate the right-hand side, let v = (v, ψ) ∈ ℋv=(v,ψ)∈H and Vℓ = (Jℓv, 0) ∈ 𝒳ℓVℓ=(Jℓv,0)∈Xℓ, where Jℓ:H1(Ω) → 𝒮1(𝒯ℓ)Jℓ:H1(Ω)→S1(Tℓ) is a Clément-type quasi-interpolation operator, see e.g. [1,49]. Note that(24)Fℓ(v − Vℓ) − ℍUℓ(v − Vℓ) = 〈f, v − Jℓv〉Ω − 〈∇Uℓ, ∇(v − Jℓv)〉Ω + 〈ϕ0 + Φℓ, v − Jℓv〉Γ + 〈ψ, (½ − 𝔎)(U0, ℓ − Uℓ) − 𝔙Φℓ〉Γ.Fℓ(v−Vℓ)−HUℓ(v−Vℓ)=〈f,v−Jℓv〉Ω−〈∇Uℓ,∇(v−Jℓv)〉Ω+〈ϕ0+Φℓ,v−Jℓv〉Γ+〈ψ,(12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ〉Γ.With standard arguments [1,49], we infer(25)|Fℓ(v−Vℓ)−HUℓ(v−Vℓ)|≲∥v∥H1(Ω)∥hℓf∥L2(Ω)+∥v∥H1(Ω)∥hℓ1/2[∂nUℓ]∥L2(⋃EℓΩ)+∥v∥H1(Ω)∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ)∥L2(Γ)+∥ψ∥H−1/2(Γ)∥(12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ∥H1/2(Γ)≤‖|v‖|(∥hℓf∥L2(Ω)+γℓ+∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ)∥L2(Γ)+∥(12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ∥H1/2(Γ)).With Lemma 3, we see ∥ hℓf ∥ L2(Ω) ≲ oscΩ, ℓ + γℓ.∥hℓf∥L2(Ω)≲oscΩ,ℓ+γℓ.Finally, it remains to estimate the last term in (25). To this end, we need the following 2D BEM result from [12, Theorem 1], see also [29,47]: Provided that the function w ∈ H1(Γ)w∈H1(Γ) has at least one zero on each element E∈EℓΓ, there holds(26)∥w∥H1/2(Γ)≤C7∥hℓ1/2w′∥L2(Γ),where the constant C7 > 0C7>0 depends only on Γ and an upper bound of κ(EℓΓ). We apply this result to w ≔ (½ − 𝔎)(U0, ℓ − Uℓ) − 𝔙Φℓw≔(12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ. First, note that U0, ℓ − Uℓ ∈ H1(Γ)U0,ℓ−Uℓ∈H1(Γ). Second, note that Φℓ ∈ L2(Γ)Φℓ∈L2(Γ). Third, recall that 𝔙:Hs − 1 / 2(Γ) → Hs + 1 / 2(Γ)V:Hs−1/2(Γ)→Hs+1/2(Γ) and 𝔎:Hs + 1 / 2(Γ) → Hs + 1 / 2(Γ)K:Hs+1/2(Γ)→Hs+1/2(Γ) are bounded linear operators for all − 1 / 2 ≤ s ≤ 1 / 2−1/2≤s≤1/2. Consequently, the case s = 1 / 2s=1/2 proves w ∈ H1(Γ)w∈H1(Γ), and the Sobolev inequality on one-dimensional manifolds implies that w is continuous. Due to the second equality in (13), we see that ∫EwdΓ=0forallE∈EℓΓ,where we simply choose Ψℓ=χE∈P0(EℓΓ) to be a characteristic function. Consequently, the continuous function w has at least one zero on each E∈EℓΓ. Now, [12, Theorem 1] yields ∥(12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ∥H1/2(Γ)≲∥hℓ1/2((12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ)′∥L2(Γ).This concludes the proof of (21). □□

Due to the triangle inequality and the aforegoing propositions, we have the following result. Corollary 5
Suppose thatu ∈ ℋu∈His the solution of(2), whereasUℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓsolves the perturbed Galerkin scheme(13). Then, (27)C8−1‖|u−Uℓ‖|≤ϱ¯ℓ≔(ϱℓ2+oscΓ,ℓ2)1/2,whereoscΓ, ℓoscΓ,ℓandϱℓϱℓare defined in Proposition2and Theorem4. The constantC8 > 0C8>0depends only onΩandσ(𝒯0)σ(T0). □□

sec.title: (h−h/2)-type error estimator
sec.p: In [5], we recently introduced some simple (h−h/2)-based error estimators for the symmetric FEM–BEM coupling. The (h − h / 2)-error(h−h/2)-error estimation strategy is a well-known technique for the a posteriori estimation of the error in the energy norm ‖|u − Uℓ‖|‖|u−Uℓ‖|; see [35] in the context of ordinary differential equations, and the works of Bank [7–9] or the monograph [1, Chapter 5] in the context of the finite element method.

Suppose that Uℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓ is the Galerkin solution (13) for some given mesh 𝒯ℓTℓ. Let T^ℓ be the uniform refinement of 𝒯ℓTℓ, i.e. all edges E∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ are halved. Let U^ℓ∈X^ℓ be the Galerkin solution (13) with respect to T^ℓ, i.e. X^ℓ≔S1(T^ℓ)×P0(E^ℓΓ),where E^ℓΓ≔T^ℓ|Γ denotes the induced boundary partition. We define the computable quantity(28)ηℓ≔‖|U^ℓ−Uℓ‖|.Since the analysis of [5] is only based on the quasi-optimality estimate (11) as well as on approximation results and inverse estimates, the results directly carry over to the Johnson–Nédélec FEM–BEM coupling. The following theorem recalls some results from [5]. Theorem 6
Letu, uℓ ∈ ℋu,uℓ∈Hbe the exact solutions of(2) and (18), respectively. LetUℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈XℓandU^ℓ∈X^ℓbe the Galerkin solution of(13), whereasUℓ⋆∈XℓandU^ℓ⋆∈X^ℓdenote the non-perturbed Galerkin solutions(8). Then, the (h−h/2)-error estimator ηℓηℓ satisfies(29)ηℓ ≤ C9‖|uℓ − Uℓ‖|.ηℓ≤C9‖|uℓ−Uℓ‖|.In particular, ηℓηℓ is always efficient in the sense that(30)C10−1ηℓ≤‖|u−Uℓ‖|+oscΓ,ℓ.Under the saturation assumption(31)‖|u−U^ℓ⋆‖|≤Csat‖|u−Uℓ⋆‖|withsomeℓ-independentconstant0<Csat<1for the non-perturbed problem, there holds reliability(32)C11−1‖|u−Uℓ‖|≤ηℓ+oscΓ,ℓ.Finally, the (h−h/2)-type error estimator(33)μℓ2≔∥∇(U^ℓ−IℓU^ℓ)∥L2(Ω)2+∥hℓ1/2(Φ^ℓ−ΠℓΦ^ℓ)∥L2(Γ)2with Iℓ:C(Ω¯)→S1(Tℓ) the nodal interpolation operator and Πℓ:L2(Γ)→P0(EℓΓ) the L2-projection, is equivalent to ηℓηℓ, i.e.(34)C12−1ηℓ≤μℓ≤C13ηℓ.The constant C9 > 0C9>0 depends only on Ω. The constants C10, C12, C13 > 0C10,C12,C13>0 depend only on Ω and σ(𝒯0)σ(T0), whereas C11 > 0C11>0 additionally depends on the saturation constant CsatCsat. □□

We remark that the saturation assumption (31) dates back to the early work [7], but may fail to hold in general [10,26]. However, it essentially states that the numerical scheme has reached an asymptotic phase [32]. For lowest-order FEM, it can be proven, if the given data are sufficiently resolved, see [26]. We stress that the saturation assumption (31) is usually observed in numerical experiments [5,32], but still remains mathematically open in the context of BEM and the FEM–BEM coupling.

Whereas the (h−h/2)-error estimator ηℓηℓ involves the non-local norm ∥ · ∥ 𝔙 ≃ ∥ · ∥ H − 1 / 2(Γ)∥·∥V≃∥·∥H−1/2(Γ), the error estimator μℓμℓ is the sum of (weighted) local L2-norms and can thus easily be used to steer an adaptive mesh-refinement. Moreover, since a numerical implementation will always return the improved Galerkin solution U^ℓ instead of UℓUℓ, it is another advantage of μℓμℓ that the computation of UℓUℓ is not needed. Finally, we stress that the Galerkin approximations Uℓ⋆ and U^ℓ⋆ are only used for theoretical reasons in Theorem 6 to formulate the saturation assumption (31). Corollary 7
With the error estimatorμℓμℓfromTheorem6and the data oscillations fromProposition2, it holds(35)μ¯ℓ≔(μℓ2+oscΓ,ℓ2)1/2≤C14‖|u−Uℓ‖|+oscΓ,ℓ.Under the saturation assumption(31), it holds(36)‖|u−Uℓ‖|≤C15μ¯ℓ.The constantC14 > 0C14>0depends only onΩandσ(𝒯0)σ(T0), whereasC15 > 0C15>0additionally depends on the saturation constantCsatCsat. □□

sec.title: Two-level error estimator
sec.p: To abbreviate notation, let Xℓ = 𝒮1(𝒯ℓ)Xℓ=S1(Tℓ) and X^ℓ=S1(T^ℓ) as well as Yℓ=P0(EℓΓ) and Y^ℓ=P0(E^ℓΓ). Let 𝒦ℓKℓ and K^ℓ denote the set of nodes for 𝒯ℓTℓ and T^ℓ, respectively.

By definition of T^ℓ, each node z∈K^ℓ⧹Kℓ is the midpoint of an edge E∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ, where EℓΩ again denotes the set of all interior edges of the triangulation 𝒯ℓTℓ. For E∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ, let ζE∈X^ℓ⧹Xℓ denote the fine-mesh hat function associated with the midpoint z of E. Let•
PℓΩ:H1(Ω)→Xℓ•
Pℓ,EΩ:H1(Ω)→span{ζE}denote the H1-orthogonal projections onto these discrete spaces. The following result is a consequence of [50, Theorem 4.1] and explicitly stated in [42, Lemma 3.1]. Lemma 8
For each functionV^ℓ∈X^ℓ, it holds(37)C16−1∥V^ℓ∥H1(Ω)2≤∥PℓΩV^ℓ∥H1(Ω)2+∑E∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ∥Pℓ,EΩV^ℓ∥H1(Ω)2≤C17∥V^ℓ∥H1(Ω)2,where the constantsC16, C17 > 0C16,C17>0depend only ondiam(Ω)diam(Ω)andσ(𝒯0)σ(T0). □□

For each boundary edge E∈EℓΓ, let φE∈Y^ℓ⧹Yℓ denote a two-level basis function with supp(φE) = Esupp(φE)=E and L2-orthogonality 〈φE, χE〉Γ = 0〈φE,χE〉Γ=0, where χEχE denotes the characteristic function on E, i.e. the Haar function φEφE with value ±1 on the first resp. second half of E. Let•
PℓΓ:H−1/2(Γ)→Yℓ•
Pℓ,EΓ:H−1/2(Γ)→span{φE}denote the orthogonal projections with respect to the 〈·, ·〉𝔙-scalar〈·,·〉V-scalar product. Then, there holds the following norm equivalence, see e.g. [27, Proposition 4.5]. Lemma 9
For discrete functionsΨ^ℓ∈Y^ℓ, it holds(38)C18−1∥Ψ^ℓ∥V2≤∥PℓΓΨ^ℓ∥V2+∑E∈EℓΓ∥Pℓ,EΓΨ^ℓ∥V2≤C19V2∥Ψ^ℓ∥V2,where the constantsC18, C19 > 0C18,C19>0depend only onΓand the K-mesh constantκ(ℰ0)κ(E0). □□

Following [42] and with the help of the aforegoing two lemmata, we now introduce the two-level error estimator τℓτℓ. Theorem 10
For each interior edgeE∈EℓΩ, we define the refinement indicators(39)τℓ(E)≔|〈f,ζE〉Ω−〈∇Uℓ,∇ζE〉Ω|∥ζE∥H1(Ω),whereas, for boundary edgesE∈EℓΓ, we define(40)τℓ(E)≔|〈f,ζE〉Ω−〈∇Uℓ,∇ζE〉Ω+〈ϕ0+Φℓ,ζE〉Γ|∥ζE∥H1(Ω)+|〈φE,(K−12)(Uℓ−U0,ℓ)−VΦℓ〉Γ|∥φE∥V.Then, the two-level error estimator(41)τℓ≔∑E∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓτℓ(E)21/2is equivalent to the (h−h/2)-error estimator ηℓηℓ, i.e. there holds(42)C20−1ηℓ≤τℓ≤C21ηℓ.The constants C20, C21 > 0C20,C21>0 depend only on Ω and σ(𝒯0)σ(T0).Proof
We define the scalar product《u, v》 ≔ ∫Ω∇u·∇v dx + ∫Ωuv dx + 〈ϕ, 𝔙ψ〉 for all u = (u, ϕ), v = (v, ψ) ∈ ℋ《u,v》≔∫Ω∇u·∇vdx+∫Ωuvdx+〈ϕ,Vψ〉forallu=(u,ϕ),v=(v,ψ)∈Hand note that 《·, ·》《·,·》 induces the norm ‖|·‖|‖|·‖| on ℋ, i.e. ‖|v| ∥ 2 = 《v, v》‖|v|∥2=《v,v》 for all v ∈ ℋv∈H. The Riesz theorem, applied to X^ℓ, guarantees the existence of a unique E^ℓ=(E^ℓ,ɛ^ℓ)∈X^ℓ with(43)《E^ℓ,V^ℓ》=Fℓ(V^ℓ)−HUℓ(V^ℓ)forallV^ℓ∈X^ℓ,where Fℓ ∈ ℋ⁎Fℓ∈H⁎ is defined in (22). Recall that (13) is equivalently stated by(44)ℍUℓ(Vℓ) = Fℓ(Vℓ) for all Vℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓ.HUℓ(Vℓ)=Fℓ(Vℓ)forallVℓ∈Xℓ.Moreover, there holds ‖|E^ℓ‖|=∥Fℓ−HUℓ∥X^ℓ⁎=∥H(U^ℓ−Uℓ)∥X^ℓ⁎≃‖|U^ℓ−Uℓ‖|,where we have used that H:X^ℓ→X^ℓ⁎ is an isomorphism as well as that HU^ℓ(V^ℓ)=Fℓ(V^ℓ) for all V^ℓ∈X^ℓ is equivalent to HU^ℓ=Fℓ in X^ℓ⁎. Let ℙℓ:ℋ → 𝒳ℓPℓ:H→Xℓ denote the orthogonal projection in ℋ, where orthogonality is understood with respect to the scalar product 《·, ·》《·,·》. According to the symmetry of ℙℓPℓ, definition (43) and (44) we observe‖|PℓE^ℓ|∥2=《PℓE^ℓ,PℓE^ℓ》=《E^ℓ,PℓE^ℓ》=Fℓ(PℓE^ℓ)−HUℓ(PℓE^ℓ)=0.Since Pℓ=(PℓΩ,PℓΓ), we may apply Lemmas 8 and 9 to see(45)‖|U^ℓ−Uℓ|∥2≃∑E∈EℓΩ∥Pℓ,EΩE^ℓ∥H1(Ω)2+∑E∈EℓΓ(∥Pℓ,EΓɛ^ℓ∥V2+∥Pℓ,EΩE^ℓ∥H1(Ω)2).The right-hand side is, in fact, the two-level error estimator τℓτℓ defined in (39) and (40). Therefore, (45) proves that the two-level error estimator τℓτℓ is equivalent to the (h−h/2)-error estimator ηℓ=‖|U^ℓ−Uℓ‖| from Theorem 6, where the equivalence constants depend only on Ω and σ(𝒯0)σ(T0). This concludes the proof. □□Corollary 11
With the two-level error estimatorτℓτℓfrom Theorem10and the data oscillations fromProposition2, it holds(46)τ¯ℓ≔(τℓ2+oscΓ,ℓ2)1/2≤C22(‖|u−Uℓ‖|+oscΓ,ℓ).Under the saturation assumption(31), it holds(47)‖|u−Uℓ‖|≤C23τ¯ℓ.The constantC22 > 0C22>0depends only onΩandσ(𝒯0)σ(T0), whereasC23 > 0C23>0additionally depends on the saturation constantCsatCsat.Proof
The proof follows from τ¯ℓ≃ηℓ+oscΓ,ℓ and estimates (30)–(32) from Theorem 6. □□

sec.title: Local estimates for residual and two-level indicators
sec.p:
According to Theorems 4, 6, and 10, it holds that τℓ ≃ ηℓ ≲ ‖|uℓ − Uℓ‖| ≲ ϱℓ.τℓ≃ηℓ≲‖|uℓ−Uℓ‖|≲ϱℓ.In this section, we prove that the estimate τℓ ≲ ϱℓτℓ≲ϱℓ holds even locally. To that end, we write the residual error estimator ϱℓϱℓ from (21) as sum(48)ϱℓ2=∑E∈EℓΩϱℓ(E)2+∑E∈EℓΓϱℓ(E)2of certain local contributions. For an interior edge E∈EℓΩ, we define(49)ϱℓ(E)2 ≔ γℓ(E)2 + oscΩ, ℓ(E)2, ϱℓ(E)2≔γℓ(E)2+oscΩ,ℓ(E)2,whereas for a boundary edge E∈EℓΓ, there holds(50)ϱℓ(E)2≔∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ)∥L2(E)2+∥hℓ1/2((12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ)′∥L2(E)2.Comparing these with the local contributions τℓ(E)τℓ(E) from (39)–(40), we obtain the following result. Theorem 12
For each interior edgeE∈EℓΩ, it holds(51)C24−1τℓ(E)≤ϱℓ(Eℓ,z)forallz∈(E∩Kℓ)⧹Γ.For each boundary edgeE∈EℓΓand the unique elementT ∈ 𝒯ℓT∈TℓwithE = ∂ T ∩ ΓE=∂T∩Γ, it holds(52)C25−1τℓ(E)≤ϱℓ(E)+ϱℓ(Eℓ,z)withz=(T∩Kℓ)⧹Γ.The constantsC24, C25 > 0C24,C25>0depend only onΩandσ(𝒯0)σ(T0).Proof
According to uniform shape regularity, we first note that ∥ ζE ∥ L2(Ω) ≃ diam(T), ∥ ζE ∥ L2(E) ≃ diam(E)1 / 2, ∥ ∇ζE ∥ L2(Ω) ≃ 1, ∥ζE∥L2(Ω)≃diam(T),∥ζE∥L2(E)≃diam(E)1/2,∥∇ζE∥L2(Ω)≃1,where T ∈ 𝒯ℓT∈Tℓ is an arbitrary element with E ⊂ ∂ TE⊂∂T. The constants in the latter estimates depend only on an upper bound of σ(𝒯ℓ)σ(Tℓ).
For an interior edge E=T+∩T−∈EℓΩ, piecewise integration by parts shows(53)τℓ(E)≤∥f∥L2(T+∪T−)∥ζE∥L2(T+∪T−)+∥[∂nUℓ]∥L2(E)∥ζE∥L2(E)∥∇ζE∥L2(Ω)≲∥hℓf∥L2(T+∪T−)+γℓ(E).For each node z ∈ (E ∩ 𝒦ℓ) ⧹ Γz∈(E∩Kℓ)⧹Γ, Lemma 3 yields ∥ hℓf ∥ L2(T + ∪ T − ) ≲ γℓ(ℰℓ, z) + oscΩ, ℓ(ℰℓ, z) = ϱℓ(ℰℓ, z)∥hℓf∥L2(T+∪T−)≲γℓ(Eℓ,z)+oscΩ,ℓ(Eℓ,z)=ϱℓ(Eℓ,z). This and γℓ(E) ≤ ϱℓ(E) ≲ ϱℓ(ℰℓ, z)γℓ(E)≤ϱℓ(E)≲ϱℓ(Eℓ,z) conclude (51).
For a boundary edge E=T∩Γ∈EℓΓ, we use integration by parts and norm equivalence ∥ φE ∥ H − 1 / 2(Γ) ≃ ∥ φE ∥ 𝔙∥φE∥H−1/2(Γ)≃∥φE∥V to estimate(54)τℓ(E)≤∥f∥L2(T)∥ζE∥L2(T)+∥ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ∥L2(E)∥ζE∥L2(E)∥∇ζE∥L2(T)+∥12−K(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ∥L2(E)∥φE∥L2(E)∥φE∥V≲∥hℓf∥L2(T)+∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ)∥L2(E)+hℓ−1/212−K(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓL2(E),where we used an inverse estimate ∥hℓ1/2φE∥L2(Γ)≲∥φE∥H−1/2(Γ) for φE∈Y^ℓ⧹Yℓ. By use of the second equation in (13), we obtain ∫Ew dΓ = 〈χE, w〉Γ = 0 for w ≔ (½ − 𝔎)(U0, ℓ − Uℓ) − 𝔙Φℓ ∈ H1(Γ).∫EwdΓ=〈χE,w〉Γ=0forw≔(12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ∈H1(Γ).Therefore, we may apply the Poincaré inequality on E to see(55)hℓ−1/212−K(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓL2(E)≤1πhℓ1/212−K(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ′L2(E).The combination of (54)–(55) thus proves τℓ(E) ≲ ∥ hℓf ∥ L2(T) + ϱℓ(E).τℓ(E)≲∥hℓf∥L2(T)+ϱℓ(E).Finally, Lemma 3 gives ∥ hℓf ∥ L2(T) ≲ ϱℓ(ℰℓ, z)∥hℓf∥L2(T)≲ϱℓ(Eℓ,z) with z = (T ∩ 𝒦ℓ) ⧹ Tz=(T∩Kℓ)⧹T the interior node of T. □□

To state the final theorem, let ΠℓΠℓ denote the L2-orthogonal projections Πℓ:L2(Γ)→P0(EℓΓ) and Πℓ:L2(Ω) → 𝒫0(𝒯ℓ)Πℓ:L2(Ω)→P0(Tℓ), respectively. Furthermore, we define the mesh quantities hℓ,max≔max{diam(E):E∈EℓΓ}and hℓ,min≔min{diam(E):E∈EℓΓ}.With these ingredients, we have the following efficiency-type estimate in case that the boundary partition EℓΓ is quasi-uniform. The proof follows by adaption of the arguments of [11] to the Johnson–Nédélec coupling. Since the details are, however, quite lengthy and technical and since the result is comparably weak (cf. the discussion in Section 5), we refer to the preprint [4]. Theorem 13
We assume that the exact solutionu = (u, ϕ)u=(u,ϕ)of(2)satisfies the additional regularity assumptionu|Γ ∈ H1(Γ)u|Γ∈H1(Γ)andϕ ∈ L2(Γ)ϕ∈L2(Γ). Then, it holds thatC26−1ϱℓ≤hℓ,max1/2hℓ,min1/2‖|u−Uℓ‖|+hℓ,maxhℓ,min1/2(∥ϕ−Πℓϕ∥L2(Γ)+∥u−Iℓu∥H1(Γ))+∥hℓ(f−Πℓf)∥L2(Ω)+∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0−Πℓϕ0)∥L2(Γ)+hℓ,max1/2∥(u0−U0,ℓ)′∥L2(Γ),where the constantC26 > 0C26>0depends only onΩ, the shape regularity constantσ(𝒯ℓ)σ(Tℓ), and the K mesh constantκ(EℓΓ). □□

sec.title: Numerical experiments
sec.p: In this section, we present a numerical example to compare the different error estimators and demonstrate the advantages of adaptive mesh refinement compared with uniform refinement. At first, we consider the error estimator νℓνℓ which is a placeholder for the presented estimators ϱℓϱℓ, μℓμℓ, or τℓτℓ. The adaptive algorithms (cf. Algorithm 14–16) use Dörfler marking [25] with an adaptivity parameter θ ∈ (0, 1)θ∈(0,1), i.e.(56)θν¯ℓ2≔θ(νℓ2+oscΓ,ℓ2)≤∑τ∈Mℓνℓ(τ)2+∑E∈Mℓ∩EℓΓoscΓ,ℓ(E)2,where Mℓ⊆Tℓ∪EℓΩ∪EℓΓ is the set of marked elements and the local contributions νℓ(τ)νℓ(τ) are defined in the respective Sections 4.2–4.4. The local data oscillations are defined by(57)oscΓ,ℓ(E)≔∥hℓ1/2(u0−U0,ℓ)′∥L2(E)forallE∈EℓΓ.We prescribe the exact solution (uint, uext)(uint,uext) of the transmission problem (1), and the data (u0, ϕ0, f)(u0,ϕ0,f) are computed from there. Note that the contribution ∥ ϕ − Φℓ ∥ 𝔙∥ϕ−Φℓ∥V to the error ‖|u − Uℓ‖|‖|u−Uℓ‖| can hardly be computed analytically. However, with the quasi-optimality (11) it holds that ‖|u−Uℓ‖|≲‖|u−Uℓ⋆‖|+oscΓ,ℓ≲∥u−Uℓ∥H1(Ω)+minΨℓ∈P0(EℓΓ)∥ϕ−Ψℓ∥V+oscΓ,ℓwith u = (u, ϕ)u=(u,ϕ) and Uℓ = (Uℓ, Φℓ)Uℓ=(Uℓ,Φℓ). In our experiment, the exterior normal derivative has additional regularity ϕ ∈ L2(Γ)ϕ∈L2(Γ). We therefore obtainminΨℓ∈P0(EℓΓ)∥ϕ−Ψℓ∥V≤∥(1−Πℓ)ϕ∥V≲∥hℓ1/2(1−Πℓ)ϕ∥L2(Γ)≤∥hℓ1/2(ϕ−Φℓ)∥L2(Γ)with Πℓ:L2(Γ) → 𝒫0(𝒯ℓ)Πℓ:L2(Γ)→P0(Tℓ) being the L2-orthogonal projection, see [15, Theorem 4.1]. Altogether, we see that(58)‖|u−Uℓ‖|≲∥u−Uℓ∥H1(Ω)+∥hℓ1/2(ϕ−Φℓ)∥L2(Γ)+oscΓ,ℓ≕errℓ(u)+errℓ(ϕ)+oscΓ,ℓ≕errℓprovides a computable upper bound for the energy error. In the same spirit, the error estimator νℓνℓ is split into(59)νℓ2=∑τ∈Tℓ∪EℓΩνℓ(τ)2+∑E∈EℓΓνℓ(E)2≕νℓ(u)2+νℓ(ϕ)2.Empirically, we have evidence that for all three estimators it holds(60)ν¯ℓ≔νℓ(u)+νℓ(ϕ)+oscΓ,ℓ≲‖|u−Uℓ‖|+oscΓ,ℓ≲νℓ(u)+νℓ(ϕ)+oscΓ,ℓ=ν¯ℓ,where we can prove the lower bound for μℓμℓ and τℓτℓ (Theorems 6 and 11). However, for ϱℓϱℓ the lower bound is only proven on quasi-uniform meshes (Theorem 13). The upper bound holds for ϱℓϱℓ without restrictions (Theorem 5) whereas it holds for μℓμℓ and ϱℓϱℓ only under the saturation assumption (Theorem 6 and 11).

In the following, we plot the five quantities errℓ(u)errℓ(u), errℓ(ϕ)errℓ(ϕ), νℓ(u)νℓ(u), νℓ(ϕ)νℓ(ϕ), and oscΓ, ℓoscΓ,ℓ from (58)–(59) over the number N=#𝒯ℓN=#Tℓ of triangles, where both axes are scaled logarithmically. We consider uniform mesh-refinement Tℓ=Tℓ(unif) with Tℓ(unif)≔T^ℓ−1, cf. Section 3.2, as well as adaptive mesh-refinement, where the sequence of meshes Tℓ=Tℓ(adap) is generated by the Algorithms 14–16 with θ = 0.25θ=0.25. Note that a decay with slope − α−α indicates some dependence 𝒪(N − α)O(N−α). For uniform meshes with mesh-size h, this corresponds to 𝒪(h2α)O(h2α). We stress that, by theory, an overall slope of α = 1 / 2α=1/2 is thus optimal with P1-finite elements.

For the adaptive mesh-refinement of Algorithms 15 and 16, recall that all integral operators have to be computed with respect to the fine mesh T^ℓ. Consequently, we then consider osc^Γ,ℓ=∥hℓ1/2(u0−U^0,ℓ)′∥L2(Γ) instead of oscΓ, ℓoscΓ,ℓ. We stress that all results of this paper hold with oscΓ, ℓoscΓ,ℓ replaced by osc^Γ,ℓ as well. Moreover, although UℓUℓ is not needed by Algorithm 15, we nevertheless plot errℓerrℓ to give a fair comparison of uniform and adaptive mesh-refinement.

Besides the experimental convergence rates, we plot errℓ(u)errℓ(u), errℓ(ϕ)errℓ(ϕ), νℓ(u)νℓ(u), νℓ(ϕ)νℓ(ϕ), and oscΓ, ℓoscΓ,ℓ (resp. osc^Γ,ℓ) over the computational time tℓtℓ.•
For uniform mesh-refinement, tℓ=tℓ(unif) is the time needed for ℓ uniform refinements of the initial mesh 𝒯0T0 to obtain 𝒯ℓTℓ, plus the time for building and solving the Galerkin system with respect to 𝒳ℓXℓ.For adaptive mesh-refinement, 𝒯ℓTℓ depends on the entire history of preceding meshes (and solutions). Therefore, the computational time has to be defined differently. Set t−1(adap)≔0.•
For adaptive mesh-refinement, tℓ=tℓ(adap) is the sum of the time tℓ−1(adap) elapsed in prior steps of the adaptive algorithm, plus the time for performing one adaptive step on the ℓ-thℓ-th mesh, i.e. steps (i)–(vi) of Algorithms 15 and 16 or steps (i)–(v) of Algorithm 14.Although this definition seems to favor uniform mesh-refinement, adaptive mesh-refinement will empirically turn out to be superior. All experiments are conducted by use of Matlab (Release 2009b) running on a common 64 Bit Linux system with 32 GB of RAM. Throughout, the occurring linear systems are solved by use of the Matlab backslash operator. For the computation of the boundary integral operators, we use the Matlab BEM library HILBERT, cf. [2]; see http://www.asc.tuwien.ac.at/abem/hilbert/ for details.

sec.title: The problem
sec.p: We consider the Z-shaped domain visualized in Fig. 2. We prescribe the exact solution of (1) as uint(x,y)=r4/7sin(47φ)inΩint,(61)uext(x,y)=x+y+0.25(x+0.125)2+(y+0.125)2inΩext,where (r, φ)(r,φ) are the polar coordinates of (x, y) ∈ ℝ2(x,y)∈R2 with respect to (0,0). Recall that (u, ϕ)(u,ϕ) denotes the exact solution of (2) and note that u = uintu=uint has a generic singularity at the reentrant corner, whereas ϕ = ∇uext·nϕ=∇uext·n is piecewise smooth. Note that − Δuint = 0 = − Δuext−Δuint=0=−Δuext, whence oscΩ, ℓ = 0oscΩ,ℓ=0 for all ℓ ∈ ℕℓ∈N.

sec.title: Experiment with residual-based error estimator ϱℓϱℓ
sec.p:
For the residual-based error estimator ϱℓϱℓ, we define the local contributions as follows: ϱℓ(E)2≔oscΩ,ℓ(E)2+γℓ(E)2forallE∈EℓΩ,(62)ϱℓ(E)2≔∥hℓ1/2(ϕ0+Φℓ−∂nUℓ)∥L2(E)2+∥hℓ1/2((12−K)(U0,ℓ−Uℓ)−VΦℓ)′∥L2(E)2forallE∈EℓΓ.The adaptive algorithm for the residual-based error estimator ϱ¯ℓ reads as follows: Algorithm 14
Input: Initial meshes (𝒯0, ℰ0)(T0,E0) for ℓ ≔ 0ℓ≔0, adaptivity parameter θ ∈ (0, 1)θ∈(0,1).(i)
Compute discrete solution Uℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓ.(ii)
Compute refinement indicators ϱ¯ℓ(τ) for all τ∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ.(iii)
Determine set Mℓ⊆EℓΩ∪EℓΓ which satisfies Dörfler marking (56).(iv)
Mark edges E ∈ ℰℓ ∩ ℳℓE∈Eℓ∩Mℓ for refinement.(v)
Generate new meshes (Tℓ+1,Eℓ+1Γ), increase counter ℓ ↦ ℓ + 1ℓ↦ℓ+1, and goto (i).Output: Sequence of error estimators (ϱ¯ℓ)ℓ∈N and discrete solutions (Uℓ)ℓ ∈ ℕ(Uℓ)ℓ∈N. □□

In Fig. 3, we plot the convergence of the error quantities from (58)–(59). Since the interior solution has a generic singularity at the reentrant corner, uniform mesh-refinement leads to a suboptimal order of convergence α = 2 / 7α=2/7, i.e. we observe 𝒪(h4 / 7)O(h4/7). For errℓ(u)errℓ(u) and ϱℓ(u)ϱℓ(u), this asymptotic is observed already on coarse meshes. For errℓ(ϕ)errℓ(ϕ) and ϱℓ(ϕ)ϱℓ(ϕ), a preasymptotic phase occurs. For adaptive mesh-refinement, we observe the optimal order of convergence α = 1 / 2α=1/2 for errℓ(u)errℓ(u) and ϱℓ(u)ϱℓ(u). Moreover, the terms errℓ(ϕ)errℓ(ϕ) and ϱℓ(ϕ)ϱℓ(ϕ) even converge with order 𝒪(h3 / 2)O(h3/2) which is optimal for the approximation of a smooth function by piecewise constants with respect to the H − 1 / 2(Γ)-normH−1/2(Γ)-norm.

The plots of Fig. 3 provide comparisons between uniform and adaptive mesh-refinement. We plot ϱ¯ from (60) as well as errℓerrℓ from (58) over the computational time. Both plots underline that the proposed adaptive algorithm is superior to uniform mesh-refinement.

sec.title: Experiment with (h−h/2)-type error estimator μℓμℓ
sec.p:
With the local contributions of μℓμℓ defined by(63)μℓ(T)2=∥(1−Iℓ)U^ℓ∥H1(T)2for triangles T ∈ 𝒯ℓT∈Tℓ and by(64)μℓ(E)2=diam(E)∥(1−Πℓ)Φ^ℓ∥L2(E)2for line segments E∈EℓΓ, we consider the convergent adaptive algorithm proposed in [5]. Algorithm 15
Input: Initial meshes (𝒯0, ℰ0)(T0,E0) for ℓ ≔ 0ℓ≔0, adaptivity parameter θ ∈ (0, 1)θ∈(0,1).(i)
Generate uniformly refined meshes T^ℓ, E^ℓΓ.(ii)
Compute discrete solution U^ℓ∈X^ℓ.(iii)
Compute refinement indicators μ¯ℓ(τ) for all τ∈Tℓ∪EℓΓ.(iv)
Determine set Mℓ⊆Tℓ∪EℓΓ which satisfies Dörfler marking (56).(v)
Mark triangles T ∈ 𝒯ℓ ∩ ℳℓT∈Tℓ∩Mℓ and boundary elements E∈EℓΓ∩Mℓ for refinement.(vi)
Generate new meshes (Tℓ+1,Eℓ+1Γ), increase counter ℓ ↦ ℓ + 1ℓ↦ℓ+1, and goto (i).Output: Sequence of error estimators (μ¯ℓ)ℓ∈N and discrete solutions (U^ℓ)ℓ∈N. □□

Fig. 4 provides the experimental convergence results for the experiment. The observations for the convergence rate are the same as in Section 4.2. The advantage in computational time takes effect after a long preasymptotic phase.

sec.title: Experiment with two-level error estimator τℓτℓ
sec.p:
The local contributions τℓ(E)τℓ(E) for E∈EℓΓ∪EℓΩ are defined in Theorem 11. Similar to the (h−h/2)-based adaptive algorithm for μ¯ℓ the algorithm for the two-level error estimator τ¯ℓ reads as follows: Algorithm 16
Input: Initial meshes (𝒯0, ℰ0)(T0,E0) for ℓ ≔ 0ℓ≔0, adaptivity parameter θ ∈ (0, 1)θ∈(0,1).(i)
Compute discrete solution Uℓ ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ∈Xℓ.(ii)
Generate uniformly refined meshes T^ℓ, E^ℓΓ.(iii)
Compute refinement indicators τ¯ℓ(τ) for all τ∈EℓΩ∪EℓΓ.(iv)
Determine set Mℓ⊆EℓΩ∪EℓΓ which satisfies Dörfler marking (56).(v)
Mark edges E ∈ ℰℓ ∩ ℳℓE∈Eℓ∩Mℓ for refinement.(vi)
Generate new meshes (Tℓ+1,Eℓ+1Γ), increase counter ℓ ↦ ℓ + 1ℓ↦ℓ+1, and goto (i).Output: Sequence of error estimators (τ¯ℓ)ℓ∈N and discrete solutions (Uℓ)ℓ ∈ ℕ(Uℓ)ℓ∈N. □□
Fig. 5 provides the experimental convergence results.

sec.title: Comparison of ϱℓϱℓ, μℓμℓ, and τℓτℓ
sec.p: Now, we want to compare the three proposed estimators in terms of convergence rate and time consumption. We plot the quantities(65)errℓ(ν)≔(errℓ(u)2+errℓ(ϕ)2+oscΓ,ℓ2)1/2aswellasν¯ℓ,where the adaptive algorithm is steered by the estimator ν¯ℓ from (60) and νℓ ∈ {ϱℓ, μℓ, τℓ}νℓ∈{ϱℓ,μℓ,τℓ}. Note that all three estimators produce the same rate of convergence, but we observe significant differences in the plot on the right-hand side, cf. Fig. 6.

sec.title: Analytical results
sec.p: In this work, we have transferred the a posteriori error analysis for some 2D FEM–BEM model problem from the symmetric coupling [22] to the Johnson–Nédélec coupling [37]. We have analytically and numerically studied certain computable upper (reliable) and lower (efficient) bounds of the FEM–BEM error ‖|u − Uℓ‖|‖|u−Uℓ‖| in the energy norm. Altogether, three different types of a posteriori error estimators and corresponding adaptive mesh-refinement techniques have been considered.

First, we adapted the weighted-residual approach from the seminal work [20]. Contrary to the original work, our variant of the estimator ϱℓϱℓ involves edge oscillations oscΩ, ℓoscΩ,ℓ instead of the volume residuals ∥ hℓf ∥ L2(Ω)∥hℓf∥L2(Ω). Thus, the interior edge jumps generically dominate the a posteriori error estimate in the sense that, in numerical experiments, adaptive mesh-refinement empirically leads to optimal convergence behavior ϱℓ = 𝒪(N − 1 / 2) = γℓϱℓ=O(N−1/2)=γℓ for the interior jumps, whereas the other contributions even appear to be of higher order. Corollary 5 states reliability of ϱℓϱℓ, i.e. up to data oscillations ϱℓϱℓ provides an upper bound for the error.

Second, we observed that the (h−h/2)-based approach of [5] carries over to the Johnson–Nédélec formulation without any modification. In Theorem 6, we collected the results from [5] on the canonical estimator ηℓηℓ and its localized and simplified variant μℓμℓ. The latter might be attractive from an implementational point of view since there is almost no overhead for its realization.

Third, we proved that the two-level error estimation technique from [42] can be used for the Johnson–Nédélec formulation as well. For our linear model problem, Theorem 10 states that this estimator is equivalent to the (h−h/2)-estimator from [5]. As a consequence, we could relax the saturation assumption of [42] in the following sense: In [42], the authors assumed linear convergence ‖|u − Uℓ + 1‖| ≤ κ‖|u − Uℓ‖|‖|u−Uℓ+1‖|≤κ‖|u−Uℓ‖| with some 0 < κ < 10<κ<1 of the adaptively generated solutions UℓUℓ and then derived reliability and efficiency of the two-level estimator τℓτℓ from that assumption. Contrary, we only assume that uniform refinement of the triangulation 𝒯ℓTℓ leads to a uniform improvement of the error, see our statement of the saturation assumption in (31). Our analysis shows that only the upper bound hinges on the saturation assumption (31), whereas efficiency holds in general. Moreover, besides the global relation τℓ ≲ ϱℓτℓ≲ϱℓ between the two-level error estimator τℓτℓ and the residual error estimator ϱℓϱℓ, we proved that this estimate holds even locally (Theorem 12). Estimates of this type have first been observed for BEM in [13].

sec.title: Numerical results
sec.p: In our numerical experiments, we observe throughout that the curves of the error estimators νℓ∈{ϱ¯ℓ,μ¯ℓ,τ¯ℓ} and the error bound errℓerrℓ are parallel for uniform as well as adaptive mesh-refinement. This gives numerical evidence for the efficiency and reliability of all estimators. First, this confirms reliability of ϱ¯ℓ (Corollary 5) as well as efficiency of μ¯ℓ (Corollary 7) and τ¯ℓ (Corollary 11). Second, it indicates that the efficiency of the residual error estimator ϱℓϱℓ holds at least under much weaker assumption than those of Theorem 13. Third, we obtain numerical evidence for the saturation assumption which guarantees the reliability of μ¯ℓ as well as τ¯ℓ.

Moreover, we observe that the three proposed adaptive algorithms regain the optimal order of convergence 𝒪(N − 1 / 2)O(N−1/2) with respect to the number N=#𝒯ℓN=#Tℓ of elements. Contrary, uniform mesh-refinement usually suffers from singularities of the unknown solution and/or the given data and only leads to suboptimal convergence behavior. With respect to computational time, we see that already for a tolerance ‖|u − Uℓ‖| ∼ 10 − 1‖|u−Uℓ‖|∼10−1 adaptive mesh-refinement is superior to a uniform approach, although the time-measurement in the adaptive case includes some error estimation which we neglect in case of uniform mesh-refinement. The tolerance 10−1 is satisfied for about N=10,000 uniform resp. N=700 adaptive elements, see Fig. 6.

An overall comparison of the considered error estimators can be concluded as follows: The adaptive algorithms driven by ϱℓϱℓ (Algorithm 14), μℓμℓ (Algorithm 15), and τℓτℓ (Algorithm 16) empirically regain the optimal order of convergence. The error curves over N=#𝒯ℓN=#Tℓ almost coincide in any case. Whereas μℓμℓ is attractive in practice since there is almost no implementational overhead, we found that the ϱℓ-basedϱℓ-based strategy is favorable for larger problems with respect to computational time. We therefore recommend to use μℓμℓ to set-up an adaptive scheme and check the implementation, while ϱℓϱℓ should be implemented to obtain the most effective realization.

sec.title: Generalization to 3D
sec.p: Similar arguments can be used to prove that the main results in Theorems 4, 6, 10, and 12 remain valid if we consider the model problem (1) and its FEM–BEM formulation (2) in 3D. The only critical difference is that an approximation result of [14,30] is needed to localize the H1 / 2-normH1/2-norm in (26), since H1-functions on 2D manifolds can be discontinuous. Then, the arclength derivative (·)′(·)′ has to be replaced by the surface gradient ∇Γ(·)∇Γ(·).

The localization of the H1 / 2-normH1/2-norm for the data approximation, cf. Proposition 2, is currently under consideration [38]. Since H1-functions on the 2D manifold Γ can be discontinuous, nodal interpolation IℓIℓ must not be used to discretize U0, ℓ = Iℓu0U0,ℓ=Iℓu0. Instead, we prove in [38] that one may use either the L2-orthogonal projection onto S1(EℓΓ) or a Scott–Zhang-type quasi-interpolation operator. Similar to the 2D case, the data approximation term then reads oscℓ=∥hℓ1/2∇Γ(u0−U0,ℓ)∥L2(Γ). Corollaries 5, 7, and 11 then hold accordingly.

sec.title: Open questions and future work
sec.p: Mathematically, not much is known about the convergence of the proposed adaptive algorithms in the sense of Uℓ → uUℓ→u as ℓ → ∞ ℓ→∞. For efficient estimators like μℓμℓ and τℓτℓ, convergence of the estimator to zero is a necessary condition. Based on the concept of estimator reduction [3], it is proven in [5] that the (h−h/2)-based Algorithm 15 leads to estimator convergence μ¯ℓ→0 as ℓ → ∞ ℓ→∞. To the best of our knowledge, there are no convergence results known for the other two adaptive algorithms which are driven by ϱℓϱℓ resp. τℓτℓ.

Moreover, quasi-optimality of all three algorithms which is empirically observed in numerical experiments, is mathematically open. Recently, there has been a huge step in the analytical understanding of convergence and quasi-optimality of adaptive finite element methods, cf. [21] and the references therein. However, even for simple model problems, quasi-optimality of adaptive boundary element methods is a major open issue, cf. [3,18,31].

In our numerical experiments, we empirically observe that adaptive mesh-refinement leads to the optimal order of convergence in each component of the error of the Galerkin solution Uℓ = (Uℓ, Φℓ) ∈ 𝒳ℓUℓ=(Uℓ,Φℓ)∈Xℓ, i.e. ∥ u − Uℓ ∥ H1(Ω) = 𝒪(N − 1 / 2)∥u−Uℓ∥H1(Ω)=O(N−1/2) and ∥ ϕ − Φℓ ∥ H − 1 / 2(Γ) = 𝒪(N − 3 / 4)∥ϕ−Φℓ∥H−1/2(Γ)=O(N−3/4), which is observed for all adaptive strategies in Figs. 3–5. In fact, the quasi-optimality (11) would only predict 𝒪(N − 1 / 2)O(N−1/2) for both terms, if this rate is possible. To the best of our knowledge, this observation is not even mathematically understood in case of a smooth solution u = (u, ϕ) ∈ H2(Ω)×H1(Γ) ⊂ ℋu=(u,ϕ)∈H2(Ω)×H1(Γ)⊂H and uniform mesh-refinement.

Finally, the saturation assumption (31) is mathematically open. In case of finite element model problems, one can prove that small data oscillation implies the saturation assumption [26]. More precisely, the triangulation has to resolve the given data so that the data approximation error is smaller than the Galerkin error. One may expect that a similar result should also hold for BEM or the FEM–BEM coupling. The non-locality of the involved boundary integral operators imposes, however, severe difficulties, and we expect that new mathematical techniques have to be developed. Anyhow, this is an additional reason why one should include the resolution of the given data into the adaptive scheme.

caption.p: For each triangle T ∈ 𝒯ℓT∈Tℓ, there is one fixed reference edge, indicated by the double line (left, top). Refinement of T is done by bisecting the reference edge, where its midpoint becomes a new node. The reference edges of the son triangles T′ ∈ 𝒯ℓ + 1T′∈Tℓ+1 are opposite to this newest vertex (left, bottom). To avoid hanging nodes, one proceeds as follows: We assume that certain edges of T, but at least the reference edge, are marked for refinement (top). Using iterated newest vertex bisection, the element is then split into 2, 3, or 4 son triangles (bottom).
Z-shaped domain and initial triangulation 𝒯0T0 for the numerical experiment.
